Key Arguments: The bill infringes on freedom of speech and creates societal division by establishing two classes of citizens.
Excessive fines and broad application of the code will limit freedom of speech on digital platforms.
The bill's scope includes 'misleading' or 'deceptive' information, hindering open discussions.
The legislation imposes unreasonable burdens on community websites and small organizations.
The bill allows private entities to enforce Misinformation Codes, raising constitutional concerns.
It assumes only the government and accredited institutions can determine truth, neglecting diverse viewpoints.
The bill threatens digital platform providers and users, resembling authoritarian practices.
It negatively impacts independent media, journalists, and bloggers, favoring government-approved entities.
Notable Quotes: The bill establishes two distinct classes of citizens, which is an affront to our democratic values.
It is impractical and unfair to expect online platforms to accurately judge what is true or false.
The bill's infringement upon the implied constitutional freedom of political communication undermines our democratic values.
The bill employs threats and intimidation against digital platform providers and ordinary users.
